metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: HTML Drag and Drop API
The HTML Drag and Drop API enables an element to be dragged and dropped.
content.html: The HTML Drag and Drop API enables an element to be dragged and dropped.

content.text: Example
Drag the W3Schools image into the second rectangle.
content.html: Drag the W3Schools image into the second rectangle.

content.text: Drag and Drop
Drag and drop is a very common feature. It is when you "grab" an object and drag it to a different location.
content.html: Drag and drop is a very common feature. It is when you "grab" an object and drag it to a different location.

content.text: Browser Support
The numbers in the table specify the first browser version that fully supports Drag and Drop.
content.html: The numbers in the table specify the first browser version that fully supports Drag and Drop.

content.code_html:
API
Drag and Drop 4.0 9.0 3.5 6.0 12.0

content.text: HTML Drag and Drop API Example
The example below is a simple drag and drop example:
content.html: The example below is a simple drag and drop example:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
id="img1" src="img_logo.gif" 
  draggable="true" ondragstart="dragstartHandler(event)" width="336" 
  height="69"

syntax_highlighting.text:
id="img1" src="img_logo.gif" 
  draggable="true" ondragstart="dragstartHandler(event)" width="336" 
  height="69"

content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE HTML>
<html>
<head>
<script>
function dragstartHandler(ev) {
  ev.dataTransfer.setData("text", ev.target.id);
}

function dragoverHandler(ev) {
  ev.preventDefault();
}

function dropHandler(ev) {
  ev.preventDefault();
  const data = ev.dataTransfer.getData("text");
  ev.target.appendChild(document.getElementById(data));
}
</script>
</head>
<body>

<div id="div1" ondrop="dropHandler(event)" ondragover="dragoverHandler(event)"></div>

<img id="img1" src="img_logo.gif" draggable="true" ondragstart="dragstartHandler(event)" width="336" height="69">

</body>
</html>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
id="img1" src="img_logo.gif" 
  draggable="true" ondragstart="dragstartHandler(event)" width="336" 
  height="69"

content.text: It might seem complicated, but lets go through all the different parts of a drag and drop event.
content.html: It might seem complicated, but lets go through all the different parts of a drag and drop event.

content.text: Make an Element Draggable
First of all: To make an element draggable, set the draggable attribute to true:
content.html: First of all: To make an element draggable, set the draggable attribute to true:

content.code_html: <img id="img1" draggable="true">

content.text: or:

content.code_html: <p id="p1" draggable="true">Draggable text</p>

content.text: What to Drag - ondragstart and setData()
Then, specify what should happen when the element is dragged.
content.html: Then, specify what should happen when the element is dragged.

content.text: In the example above, the ondragstart attribute of the element calls a function (dragstartHandler(ev)), that specifies what data to be dragged.
content.html: In the example above, the ondragstart attribute of the <img> element calls a function (dragstartHandler(ev)), that specifies what data to be dragged.

content.text: The dataTransfer.setData() method sets the data type and the value of the dragged data:
content.html: The dataTransfer.setData() method sets the data type and the value of the dragged data:

content.code_html:
function dragstartHandler(ev) {
  ev.dataTransfer.setData("text", ev.target.id);
}

content.text: In this case, the data type is "text" and the value is the id of the draggable element ("img1").
content.html: In this case, the data type is "text" and the value is the id of the draggable element ("img1").

content.text: Where to Drop - ondragover
The ondragover attrribute of the <div> element calls a function (dragoverHandler(ev)), that specifies where the dragged data can be dropped.
content.html: The ondragover attrribute of the <div> element calls a function (dragoverHandler(ev)), that specifies where the dragged data can be dropped.

content.text: By default, data/elements cannot be dropped in other elements. To allow a drop, we must prevent the default handling of the element.
content.html: By default, data/elements cannot be dropped in other elements. To allow a drop, we must prevent the default handling of the element.

content.text: This is done by calling the preventDefault() method for the ondragover event:
content.html: This is done by calling the preventDefault() method for the ondragover event:

content.code_html:
function dragoverHandler(ev) {
  ev.preventDefault();
}

content.text: Do the Drop - ondrop
When the dragged data is dropped, a drop event occurs.
content.html: When the dragged data is dropped, a drop event occurs.

content.text: In the example above, the ondrop attribute of the <div> element calls a function, dropHandler(event):
content.html: In the example above, the ondrop attribute of the <div> element calls a function, dropHandler(event):

content.code_html:
function dropHandler(ev) {
  ev.preventDefault();
  const data = ev.dataTransfer.getData("text");
  ev.target.appendChild(document.getElementById(data));
}

content.text: Code explained:
More Examples

content.code: W3Schools.com
content.code_html:
<script>
function dragstartHandler(ev) {
  ev.dataTransfer.setData("text", ev.target.id);
}

function dragoverHandler(ev) {
  ev.preventDefault();
}

function dropHandler(ev) {
  ev.preventDefault();
  const data = ev.dataTransfer.getData("text");
  ev.target.appendChild(document.getElementById(data));
}
</script>
</head>
<body>

<div id="div1" ondrop="dropHandler(event)" ondragover="dragoverHandler(event)"></div>

<h1 id="h1" draggable="true" ondragstart="dragstartHandler(event)">W3Schools.com</h1>

content.code: W3Schools.com
content.code_html:
<script>
function dragstartHandler(ev) {
  ev.dataTransfer.setData("text", ev.target.id);
}

function dragoverHandler(ev) {
  ev.preventDefault();
}

function dropHandler(ev) {
  ev.preventDefault();
  const data = ev.dataTransfer.getData("text");
  ev.target.appendChild(document.getElementById(data));
}
</script>
</head>
<body>

<div id="div1" ondrop="dropHandler(event)" ondragover="dragoverHandler(event)"></div>

<a id="link1" href="https://w3schools.com" draggable="true" ondragstart="dragstartHandler(event)">W3Schools.com</a>
